headline: Reserve Bank Slashes Interest Rates to 3%, Sparking Fierce Parliamentary Debate on Economic Recovery and Cost of Living
summary: Parliament was dominated by major economic news as the Reserve Bank cut the official cash rate to 3%, providing potential relief for mortgage holders. The Government championed the move as proof of its economic management, while the Opposition highlighted ongoing industrial action, including a nationwide teachers' strike, and rising Pasifika unemployment as evidence of continued hardship for New Zealanders.

topicSummaries.topic: Reserve Bank Cuts Official Cash Rate to 3% Amid Economic Debate
topicSummaries.content: Finance Minister Nicola Willis announced the Reserve Bank had lowered the Official Cash Rate (OCR) by 25 basis points to 3%, its lowest level in three years. She highlighted this as significant cost-of-living relief, noting a family with a $500,000 floating mortgage would save around $330 a fortnight. The Government argued its disciplined spending had created room for the cut. However, Labour's Barbara Edmonds challenged this narrative, pointing to a 56.6% increase in KiwiSaver hardship withdrawals and a 37% rise in company liquidations as signs the economic recovery was not being felt by ordinary New Zealanders and businesses.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicola Willis (Minister of Finance)
keyExchanges.quote: The official cash rate (OCR) has been reduced by a further 25 basis points, taking the rate down to 3 percent. That is a far cry from the 5.5 percent cash rate reached in May 2023. Over the past year, OCR reductions have lowered the cost of borrowing for New Zealand households and businesses, delivering much-needed cost of living relief and supporting the economic recovery.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Barbara Edmonds (Labour—Mana)
keyExchanges.quote: How can she stand by her statement from March this year that the "recovery is under way" when KiwiSaver members withdrew over $470 million for hardship reasons in the past year, a 56.6 percent increase?

topicSummaries.topic: Teachers Strike Over 1% Pay Offer as PM Urges Negotiation
topicSummaries.content: The Prime Minister faced intense questioning from Green Party Co-leader Marama Davidson regarding the nationwide teachers' strike. Davidson highlighted that the strike was prompted by a 1% pay offer at a time when inflation stands at 2.7%, constituting a real-terms pay cut. Prime Minister Christopher Luxon defended his government's commitment to ensuring wages outpace inflation but refused to discuss specifics of the offer, urging unions to return to the negotiating table rather than resorting to strike action early in the process.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Marama Davidson (Co-Leader—Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Then does he accept that wages not keeping pace with inflation is a pay cut in real terms, and, if so, when will he "Up the teachers"? [Holds up protest sign bearing these words]

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, I'd say that that's what this Government is working incredibly hard to do, which is to make sure that wage growth is ahead of inflation, unlike what we saw with the previous administration, where inflation was well ahead of wages.

topicSummaries.topic: KiwiRail Finalises $144M Settlement for Cancelled iReX Ferry Project
topicSummaries.content: Rail Minister Winston Peters announced that KiwiRail has made a final settlement payment of $144 million to Hyundai, concluding the cancelled iReX inter-island ferry project. Peters heavily criticised the previous government's handling of the project, which he labelled a "sorry saga of mismanagement," stating it had spent $671 million for little result. He argued that cancelling the project, which Treasury forecast could have cost up to $4 billion, had saved taxpayers billions and that his government's "no-nonsense ferry solution" would secure the Interislander's future.

keyExchanges.speaker: Jamie Arbuckle (NZ First)
keyExchanges.quote: Why is he so confident his plan will save the taxpayers billions?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Winston Peters (Minister for Rail)
keyExchanges.quote: Our solution focuses on what's required for Wellington and Picton and doesn't get sucked into nonsense like the Project iReX, which sought to knock down everything and then build utopia in its place. Once they got control of 21, they specified flash new terminal buildings, "Taj Mahals" in Picton; they planned to lift the yards metres into the air and completely over-specify the road and rail yards.

topicSummaries.topic: Major RMA Overhaul Receives Royal Assent, Halting Council Plan-Making
topicSummaries.content: Minister Chris Bishop announced that the Resource Management (Consenting and Other System Changes) Amendment Act has received Royal assent, marking a significant step in the government's planning system reforms. The Act aims to simplify and speed up consents for renewable energy, housing, and primary sector activities. A key provision is a default stop to most new council plan-making, a move Bishop said would save ratepayer money on "pricey, pointless policy processes" ahead of two new bills intended to fully replace the RMA before the end of the year.

keyExchanges.speaker: Miles Anderson (National—Waitaki)
keyExchanges.quote: Why is the Government replacing our planning system?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Bishop (Minister responsible for RMA Reform)
keyExchanges.quote: Because we spend $1.3 billion a year on consenting costs for infrastructure; because we have some of the most expensive house prices in the developed world; because, in a country with abundant renewable energy, it takes years and years to consent a wind farm or a solar farm... The RMA is soon to be gone-burger and growth and prosperity is on the way.

topicSummaries.topic: Heated Debate Over Rising Pasifika Unemployment After Funding Cut
topicSummaries.content: A tense exchange occurred between Labour's Carmel Sepuloni and Social Development Minister Louise Upston over Pasifika unemployment, which has doubled since the government took office, with 6,100 more Pasifika people now unemployed compared to last year. Sepuloni questioned the government's decision to cut $22 million from the Tupu Aotearoa programme, a specific Pasifika employment initiative. Upston defended the move, stating the programme's functions were absorbed by the Ministry of Social Development to leverage existing, stronger programmes and that the government was focused on fixing the "mess that we were given."

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Carmel Sepuloni (Deputy Leader—Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Does she understand why Pasifika people might be taking it personally when their unemployment rate is double what it was when the Government came into office, more than double the general unemployment rate, and her Government is making things worse for them each and every day?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Louise Upston (Minister for Social Development and Employment)
keyExchanges.quote: No, because Pasifika people know what we have inherited and what we go to work on each and every day to improve the opportunities and fix the mess that we were given.

topicSummaries.topic: Medsafe Slashes Medicine Approval Times; 'Rule of Two' Policy Incoming
topicSummaries.content: Associate Health Minister David Seymour praised Medsafe for cutting new medicine approval times by over 100 working days in the last two years, aligning New Zealand with countries like Australia and Canada. Seymour also detailed upcoming legislation to introduce a "Rule of Two" policy. Under this rule, if a medicine has already been approved by two recognised international jurisdictions, it will be approved for use in New Zealand within 30 days, a move he said would be an "exceptional improvement" for patients.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon David Seymour (Associate Minister of Health)
keyExchanges.quote: This Government is bringing legislation through Parliament that will introduce the Rule of Two. Early next year, the rule will be that if a medicine is allowed by two other similar jurisdictions... if two of those countries have allowed something, then within 30 days they'll be allowed here in New Zealand.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Carmel Sepuloni (Deputy Leader—Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: How can we take him seriously when he's taking the piss out of someone's mental health?

conclusion: The day's proceedings crystallized the core political divide: the government celebrating headline economic relief through lower interest rates, against an opposition focused on persistent struggles in wages, employment, and the cost of living.
